block.p: Stocks Rebound Slightly As Investors Seek Bargains Stock market gauges rose slightly as investors sought bargains but shunned multinational companies with exposure to the financial turmoil in Asia .

The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 37.37 points, to 1,753.12, erasing Monday's 29.30-point decline. The 2.18 percent gain was the largest percentage increase in the barometer in more than three months. Among the big gainers on the Nasdaq were Intel, Microsoft and Dell Computer. Dell jumped 5.9 percent on news it was in talk with Microsoft to custom-design personal computers. [Page D10.]

Pressmans to Give Up Titles Bob and Gene Pressman will step down soon as co-chief executives of Barney's, the luxury fashion retailer started by their grandfather, executives involved in the negotiations said. The two will remain consultants to the company as it continues to emerge from bankruptcy protection. [D2.]

Larger Issue Underlies G.M. Strikes The strikes crippling General Motors, while partly about job security and workplace safety, reflect a broader struggle over how America's auto industry will make vehicles. G.M. wants to embrace efficient techniques it uses in countries like Brazil. But where G.M. sees efficiency, the United Automobile Workers union sees a threat. [A1.]
Pfizer to Sell Schneider Unit Pfizer will sell its Schneider Worldwide unit, which makes stents used to hold open arteries, to Boston Scientific for $2.1 billion. [D11.]

Obstacle Looms for Financial Bill The Clinton Administration all but doomed efforts to update the nation's Depression-era financial services law this year, saying it would not budge from its opposition to the bill passed last month by the House and that it wants to start over next year. [D6.]

No Harm Seen by Merger Wave The White House and the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, agreed in testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee that there was little evidence of excessive consolidation from the mergers sweeping the banking, telecommunications and military contracting industries. [D22.]

Consumer Prices Up 0.3% in May Price increases for lettuce, cigarettes, gasoline and prescription drugs pushed up consumer inflation by three-tenths of 1 percent in May, the largest increase in 17 months. In another report, construction starts on new homes were down seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, to an annual rate of 1.53 million units. [D10.]

Merck Expected to Get Windfall Astra, the Swedish drug giant, is expected to buy Merck's share of the two companies' joint venture. That, plus last month's DuPont deal, means Merck is looking at a multibillion-dollar windfall. Market Place. [D9.]
Jury Rejects Workers' Injury Claims A Federal jury rejected claims by nine people that they were injured by using computer keyboards made by Digital Equipment. [D2.]

Some Miss Big Payday at Goldman For retired, resigned and might-have-been partners of Goldman, Sachs the announcement on Monday that the private investment bank would go public was the ultimate missed opportunity. These limited partners will not receive big bonuses as the investment bank issues shares. [D9.]
Fee Cap Backed in Tobacco Cases The Senate voted to limit lawyers' fees in suits against cigarette makers. [A1.]

A Managed Care Failure in California The California Medical Association is closing the managed care company that it and 7,500 of its member physicians created to take on the state's big H.M.O.'s. After two and a half years, three chief executives and $11 million in losses, the association's company, California Advantage, will file for bankruptcy. [A12.]
